data.title: The Gilded Age Revisited: 10 Must-Read Books for a Deeper Dive into This Opulent Era
data.meta_description: Check out these nonfiction picks perfect for fans of HBO's The Gilded Age.
data.text:
By Serena Dresslar, Librarian II

November 17, 2023

An era of both abject poverty and unprecedented wealth, the Gilded Age left its mark on New York City where the opulent lifestyles of the city’s rich and famous captured the public imagination. If you’re a historian with champagne taste or binging season two of The Gilded Age, check out these books about NYC’s wealthiest families. Or read more about the dawn of the Black upper class in the blog post, A Short Bibliography of the Black Elite: Books About Black High Society in the Gilded Age.

The Gilded Age: 1876-1912 Overture to the American Century

by Alan Axelrod

A noted historian revisits American life and thought between the 1870s and 1900, sharing political cartoons, engravings, news clippings and other ephemera that help bring this fascinating period to life and offering some interesting parallels to our own time.

What Would Mrs. Astor Do?: The Essential Guide to the Manners and Mores of the Gilded Age

by Cecelia Tichi

An old money heiress of the first order, Mrs. Caroline Astor became convinced that she was uniquely qualified to uphold the manners and mores of this time, prompting members of high society to take note, in this beautifully illustrated tour of the Gilded Age that shows New York at its most fashionable.

Empty Mansions: The Mysterious Life of Huguette Clark and the Spending of a Great American Fortune

by Bill Dedman and Paul Clark Newell, Jr.

A cousin of Huguette Clark and a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist trace the life of the reclusive American heiress against a backdrop of the now-infamous W. A. Clark family and include coverage of the internet sensation and elder-abuse investigation that occurred at the end of her life.

The Richest Woman in America: Hetty Green in the Gilded Age

by Janet Wallach

Traces the story of the turn-of-the-20th-century tycoon, offering insight into her abandonment by her mother, the Quaker values that marked her life, and the brash investment practices that caused her to be heralded and denounced by those who knew her.

Diamonds and Deadlines: A Tale of Greed, Deceit, and a Female Tycoon in the Gilded Age

by Betsy Prioleau

The first major biography of the unsung hero of women’s suffrage, who for 20 years ran Frank Leslie Publishing, the country’s largest publishing company while becoming a glamorous and controversial celebrity and tastemaker.

American Eve: Evelyn Nesbit, Stanford White, the Birth of the "It" Girl, and the Crime of the Century

by Paula Uruburu

Documents the scandal-marked career of the early 20th-century model and celebrity, discussing her early fame, her marriage to millionaire Harry K. Thaw, and her infamous relationship with her murdered lover, famed architect Stanford White.

When the Astors Owned New York: Blue Bloods and Grand Hotels in a Gilded Age

by Justin Kaplan

Traces the lives of cousins William Waldorf Astor and John Jacob Astor IV, rivals who pursued separate ambitions, built the original Waldorf-Astoria hotel, and influenced social behavior before John Jacob perished aboard the Titanic.

The Glitter and the Gold: The American Duchess-in Her Own Words

by Consuelo Vanderbilt Balsan

An updated edition of the life story of the American heiress and Duchess of Marlborough whose experiences inspired the character of Downtown Abby's Lady Grantham describes her arranged marriage, her observations of the intricate hierarchy of her home in Blenheim Palace and her encounters with famous historical figures.

The Gilded Age in New York, 1870-1910

by Esther Crain

An expansive exploration of The Gilded Age in New York City, from of the extravagant lifestyles and magnificent mansions of the ultra-rich to the daily doings of the wretchedly poor who lived in the shadows of their newly constructed skyscrapers. Written by the curator of Ephemeral New York and illustrated with hundreds of rarely-seen images.

Heiresses: The Lives of the Million Dollar Babies

by Laura Thompson

Looks at the lives of heiresses throughout history such as Consuelo Vanderbilt, the original American “Dollar Heiress,” Barbara Hutton, the Woolworth heiress and Patty Hearst, the notorious heiress to a newspaper fortune turned terrorist.
